Detailed Description

An page is a single, focused thing that the user can do.

There are two methods almost all subclasses of Page will implement:

  • onInit(Persistence*) is where you initialize your page.

  • onPause is where you deal with the user leaving your page. Most importantly, any changes made by the user should at this point be committed (usually to the content::ContentProvider holding the data).

To be of use with Context#startPage, all page classes must have a corresponding declaration in their package's Manifest.xml.

The Page class is an important part of an application's overall lifecycle, and the way pages are launched and put together is a fundamental part of the platform's application model. For a detailed perspective on the structure of applications and lifecycles.

Topics covered here:

  1. Page Lifecycle
  2. Starting Pages and Getting Results
  3. Saving Persistent State
  4. Process Lifecycle

Page Lifecycle

Pages in the system are managed as an page stack. When a new page is started, it is placed on the top of the stack and becomes the running page -- the previous page always remains below it in the stack, and will not come to the foreground again until the new page exits.

An page has essentially four states:

  • If an page in the foreground of the screen (at the top of the stack), it is active or running.
  • If an page has lost focus but is still visible (that is, a new non-full-sized or transparent page has focus on top of your page), it is paused. A paused page is completely alive (it maintains all state and member information and remains attached to the window manager), but can be killed by the system in extreme low memory situations.
  • If an page is completely obscured by another page, it is stopped. It still retains all state and member information, however, it is no longer visible to the user so its window is hidden and it will often be killed by the system when memory is needed elsewhere.
  • If an page is paused or stopped, the system can drop the page from memory by either asking it to finish, or simply killing its process. When it is displayed again to the user, it must be completely restarted and restored to its previous state.

There are three key loops you may be interested in monitoring within your page:

  • The entire lifetime of an page happens between the first call to core::Page#onInit through to a single final call to core::Page#onTear. An page will do all setup of "global" state in onInit(), and release all remaining resources in onDestroy(). For example, if it has a thread running in the background to download data from the network, it may create that thread in onInit() and then stop the thread in onDestroy().

  • The visible lifetime of an page happens between a call to core::Page#onStart until a corresponding call to core::Page#onStop. During this time the user can see the page on-screen, though it may not be in the foreground and interacting with the user. Between these two methods you can maintain resources that are needed to show the page to the user. For example, you can register a core::Subscriber in onStart() to monitor for changes that impact your UI, and unregister it in onStop() when the user an no longer see what you are displaying. The onStart() and onStop() methods can be called multiple times, as the page becomes visible and hidden to the user.

  • The foreground lifetime of an page happens between a call to core::Page#onResume until a corresponding call to core::Page#onPause. During this time the page is in front of all other pages and interacting with the user. An page can frequently go between the resumed and paused states -- for example when the device goes to sleep, when an page result is delivered, when a new dialogue is delivered -- so the code in these methods should be fairly lightweight.

The entire lifecycle of an page is defined by the following Page methods. All of these are hooks that you can override to do appropriate work when the page changes state. All pages will implement core::Page#onInit to do their initial setup; many will also implement core::Page#onPause to commit changes to data and otherwise prepare to stop interacting with the user. You should always call up to your superclass when implementing these methods.

 class MyPage: public gaia::core::Page
 {
 public:
      MyPage();
      virtual ~MyPage();
      virtual void onInit(gaia::core::Persistence* p);
      virtual void onRestart();
      virtual void onStart();
      virtual void onResume();
      virtual void onPause();
      virtual void onStop();
      virtual void onTear();
 };

An example for use Context and PageManager in onInit. 

 #include "MyPage.h"
 #include <gaia/core/Persistence.h>

 void MyPage::onInit(Persistence* p)
 {
     gaia::base::String* str;
     this->setDefaultKeyMode(DEFAULT_KEYS_DISABLE);
     Context* context =  new Context(this);
     str = context->getPackageName();
     GLOGD("context->getPackageName = %s", str->string());
     delete str;
     PageManager* pageManager = new PageManager(context);
     bool bIsMonkey = pageManager->isUserAMonkey();
     delete pageManager;
     delete Context;
 }

Starting Pages and Getting Results

The core::Page#startPage method is used to start a new page, which will be placed at the top of the page stack. It takes a single argument, an Demand, which describes the page to be executed.

Sometimes you want to get a result back from an page when it ends. For example, you may start an page that lets the user pick a person in a list of contacts; when it ends, it returns the person that was selected. To do this, you call the Page#startPageForResult(Demand*, int32_t) version with a second integer parameter identifying the call. The result will come back through your Page#onPageResult method.

When an page exits, it can call Page#setResult(int32_t) to return data back to its parent. It must always supply a result code, which can be the standard results RESULT_CANCELED, RESULT_OK, or any custom values starting at RESULT_FIRST_USER. In addition, it can optionally return back an Demand containing any additional data it wants. All of this information appears back on the parent's Page::onPageResult(), along with the integer identifier it originally supplied.

If a child page fails for any reason (such as crashing), the parent page will receive a result with the code RESULT_CANCELED. 

 public class MyPage extends Page {
     ...

     static final int32_t PICK_CONTACT_REQUEST = 0;

     protected boolean onKeyDown(int32_t keyCode, KeyEvent event) {
         if (keyCode == KeyEvent.KEYCODE_DPAD_CENTER) {
             // When the user center presses, let them pick a contact.
             startPageForResult(
                 new Demand(Demand.ACTION_PICK,
                 new Uri("content://contacts")),
                 PICK_CONTACT_REQUEST);
            return true;
         }
         return false;
     }

     protected void onPageResult(int32_t requestCode, int32_t resultCode,
             Demand data) {
         if (requestCode == PICK_CONTACT_REQUEST) {
             if (resultCode == RESULT_OK) {
                 // A contact was picked.  Here we will just display it
                 // to the user.
                 startPage(new Demand(Demand.ACTION_VIEW, data));
             }
         }
     }
 }

Saving Persistent State

There are generally two kinds of persistent state than an page will deal with: shared document-like data (typically stored in a SQLite database using a content::ContentProvider) and internal state such as user preferences.

For content provider data, we suggest that pages use a "edit in place" user model. That is, any edits a user makes are effectively made immediately without requiring an additional confirmation step. Supporting this model is generally a simple matter of following two rules:

  • When creating a new document, the backing database entry or file for it is created immediately. For example, if the user chooses to write a new e-mail, a new entry for that e-mail is created as soon as they start entering data, so that if they go to any other page after that point this e-mail will now appear in the list of drafts.

  • When an page's onPause() method is called, it should commit to the backing content provider or file any changes the user has made. This ensures that those changes will be seen by any other page that is about to run. You will probably want to commit your data even more aggressively at key times during your page's lifecycle: for example before starting a new page, before finishing your own page, when the user switches between input fields, etc.

This model is designed to prevent data loss when a user is navigating between pages, and allows the system to safely kill an page (because system resources are needed somewhere else) at any time after it has been paused. Note this implies that the user pressing BACK from your page does not mean "cancel" -- it means to leave the page with its current contents saved away. Cancelling edits in an page must be provided through some other mechanism, such as an explicit "revert" or "undo" option.

See the content::ContentProvider for more information about content providers. These are a key aspect of how different pages invoke and propagate data between themselves.

The Page class also provides an API for managing internal persistent state associated with an page. This can be used, for example, to remember the user's preferred initial display in a calendar (day view or week view) or the user's default home page in a web browser.

Process Lifecycle

The Android system attempts to keep application process around for as long as possible, but eventually will need to remove old processes when memory runs low. As described in Page Lifecycle, the decision about which process to remove is intimately tied to the state of the user's interaction with it. In general, there are four states a process can be in based on the pages running in it, listed here in order of importance. The system will kill less important processes (the last ones) before it resorts to killing more important processes (the first ones).

  1. The foreground page (the page at the top of the screen that the user is currently interacting with) is considered the most important. Its process will only be killed as a last resort, if it uses more memory than is available on the device. Generally at this point the device has reached a memory paging state, so this is required in order to keep the user interface responsive.

  2. A visible page (an page that is visible to the user but not in the foreground, such as one sitting behind a foreground dialog) is considered extremely important and will not be killed unless that is required to keep the foreground page running.

  3. A background page (an page that is not visible to the user and has been paused) is no longer critical, so the system may safely kill its process to reclaim memory for other foreground or visible processes. If its process needs to be killed, when the user navigates back to the page (making it visible on the screen again), its onInit method will be called with the savedInstanceState it had previously supplied in onSaveInstanceState so that it can restart itself in the same state as the user last left it.

  4. An empty process is one hosting no pages or other application components (such as Delegate or core::Subscriber classes). These are killed very quickly by the system as memory becomes low. For this reason, any background operation you do outside of an page must be executed in the context of an page Subscriber or Service to ensure that the system knows it needs to keep your process around.

Sometimes an Page may need to do a long-running operation that exists independently of the page lifecycle itself. An example may be a camera application that allows you to upload a picture to a web site. The upload may take a long time, and the application should allow the user to leave the application will it is executing. To accomplish this, your Page should start a core::Delegate in which the upload takes place. This allows the system to properly prioritize your process (considering it to be more important than other non-visible applications) for the duration of the upload, independent of whether the original page is paused, stopped, or finished.

Member Function Documentation

PendingDemand* gaia::core::Page::createPendingResultN ( int32_t  requestCode,
Demand *  data,
int32_t  flags 
)

Create a new PendingDemand object which you can hand to others for them to use to send result data back to your onPageResult callback.

The created object will be either one-shot (becoming invalid after a result is sent back) or multiple (allowing any number of results to be sent through it).

Parameters:
requestCodePrivate request code for the sender that will be associated with the result data when it is returned. The sender can not modify this value, allowing you to identify incoming results.
dataDefault data to supply in the result, which may be modified by the sender.
flagsMay be PendingDemand.FLAG_ONE_SHOT, PendingDemand.FLAG_NO_CREATE, PendingDemand.FLAG_CANCEL_CURRENT, PendingDemand.FLAG_UPDATE_CURRENT.
Returns:
Returns an existing or new PendingDemand matching the given parameters. May return null only if PendingDemand#FLAG_NO_CREATE has been supplied.
See also:
PendingDemand
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::dispatchGenericMotionEvent ( MotionEvent *  ev) [virtual]

Called to process generic motion events.

You can override this to intercept all generic motion events before they are dispatched to the window. Be sure to call this implementation for generic motion events that should be handled normally.

Returns:
Return true if this event was consumed.

void gaia::core::Page::finish ( )

Call this when your activity is done and should be closed.

The PageResult is propagated back to whoever launched you via onPageResult.

Reimplemented in gaia::accounts::AccountAuthenticatorPage.

Referenced by gaia::testing::PageInstrumentationTestCase< TestPage, TestFixture >::TearDown().

virtual void gaia::core::Page::finishFirstDraw ( ) [protected, virtual]

This is called when Page finishs first drawing.

This function does not run on the UI thread. Be sure not doing UI operation on this function directly.

void gaia::core::Page::finishFromChild ( Page *  child)

This is called when a child activity of this one calls its finish method.

The default implementation simply calls finish on this page (the parent), finishing the entire group.

Parameters:
childThe activity making the call.
See also:
finish

Parameters:

gaia::base::String gaia::core::Page::getCallingPackage ( )

Return the name of the package that invoked this activity.

This is who the data in setResult will be sent to. You can use this information to validate that the recipient is allowed to receive the data.

Note: if the calling activity is not expecting a result (that is it did not use the startPageForResult form that includes a request code), then the calling package will be null.

Returns:
The package of the activity that will receive your reply, or null if none.
ComponentName gaia::core::Page::getCallingPage ( )

Return the name of the page that invoked this page.

This is who the data in setResult will be sent to. You can use this information to validate that the recipient is allowed to receive the data.

Note: if the calling page is not expecting a result (that is it did not use the startPageForResult form that includes a request code), then the calling package will be null.

Returns:
The full of the activity that will receive your reply, or null if none.
int32_t gaia::core::Page::getChangingConfigurations ( )

If this activity is being destroyed because it can not handle a configuration parameter being changed (and thus its #onConfigurationChanged(Configuration) method is not being called), then you can use this method to discover the set of changes that have occurred while in the process of being destroyed.

Note that there is no guarantee that these will be accurate (other changes could have happened at any time), so you should only use this as an optimization hint.

Returns:
Returns a bit field of the configuration parameters that are changing, as defined by the Configuration class.

Check to see whether this activity is in the process of being destroyed in order to be recreated with a new configuration.

This is often used in onStop to determine whether the state needs to be cleaned up or will be passed on to the next instance of the activity via #onRetainNonConfigurationInstance.

Returns:
If the activity is being torn down in order to be recreated with a new configuration, returns true; else returns false.

This is often used in onPause to determine whether the page is simply pausing or completely finishing.

Returns:

virtual void gaia::core::Page::onConfigurationChanged ( gaia::content::Configuration *const  newConfig) [virtual]

Called by the system when the device configuration changes while your page is running.

Note that this will only be called if you have selected configurations you would like to handle with the #R attribute in your manifest. If any configuration change occurs that is not selected to be reported by that attribute, then instead of reporting it the system will stop and restart the page (to have it launched with the new configuration).

At the time that this function has been called, your Resources object will have been updated to return resource values matching the new configuration.

Parameters:
newConfigThe new device configuration.
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onContentChanged ( ) [virtual]
virtual gaia::base::String gaia::core::Page::onCreateDescription ( ) [virtual]

Generate a new description for this page.

This method is called before pausing the page and can, if desired, return some textual description of its current state to be displayed to the user. *

The default implementation returns null, which will cause you to inherit the description from the previous page. If all pages return null, generally the label of the top page will be used as the description.

Returns:
A description of what the user is doing. It should be short and sweet (only a few words).
See also:
onCreateThumbnail, onSaveInstanceState, onPause
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onCreateOptionsMenu ( Menu *  menu) [virtual]

Initialize the contents of the Page's standard options menu.

You should place your menu items in to menu.

This is only called once, the first time the options menu is displayed. To update the menu every time it is displayed, see onPrepareOptionsMenu.

You can safely hold on to menu (and any items created from it), making modifications to it as desired, until the next time onCreateOptionsMenu() is called.

When you add items to the menu, you can implement the Page's onOptionsItemSelected method to handle them there.

Parameters:
menuThe options menu in which you place your items.
Returns:
You must return true for the menu to be displayed; if you return false it will not be shown.
See also:
onPrepareOptionsMenu, onOptionsItemSelected
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onCreateThumbnail ( gaia::graphics::Bitmap *  outBitmap,
gaia::graphics::Canvas *  canvas 
) [virtual]

Generate a new thumbnail for this page.

This method is called before pausing the page, and should draw into outBitmap the imagery for the desired thumbnail in the dimensions of that bitmap. It can use the given canvas, which is configured to draw into the bitmap, for rendering if desired.

The default implementation renders the Screen's current view hierarchy into the canvas to generate a thumbnail.

If you return false, the bitmap will be filled with a default thumbnail.

Parameters:
outBitmapThe bitmap to contain the thumbnail.
canvasCan be used to render into the bitmap.
Returns:
Return true if you have drawn into the bitmap; otherwise after you return it will be filled with a default thumbnail.
See also:
onCreateDescription, onSaveInstanceState, onPause
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onDetachedFromWindow ( ) [virtual]

Called when the main window associated with the page has been detached from the window manager.

virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onGenericMotionEvent ( MotionEvent *  event) [virtual]

Called when a generic motion event was not handled by any of the views inside of the activity.

Generic motion events describe joystick movements, mouse hovers, track pad touches, scroll wheel movements and other input events. The source of the motion event specifies the class of input that was received. Implementations of this method must examine the bits in the source before processing the event. The following code example shows how this is done.

Generic motion events with source class InputDevice#SOURCE_CLASS_POINTER are delivered to the view under the pointer. All other generic motion events are delivered to the focused view.

Parameters:
eventThe generic motion event being processed.
Returns:
Return true if you have consumed the event, false if you haven't. The default implementation always returns false.
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onInit ( Persistence *  savedInstanceState) [protected, virtual]

Called when the page is starting.

You can call finish from within this function, in which case onDestroy() will be immediately called without any of the rest of the page lifecycle (onStart, onResume, onPause, etc) executing.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown. savedInstanceState If the page is being re-initialized after previously being shut down then this Persistence contains the data it most recently supplied in onSaveInstanceState. Note: Otherwise it is null.

See also:
onStart, onSaveInstanceState, onRestoreInstanceState

Reimplemented in gaia::accounts::AccountAuthenticatorPage.

virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onKeyDown ( int32_t  keyCode,
KeyEvent *  event 
) [virtual]

Called when a key was pressed down and not handled by any of the views inside of the page.

So, for example, key presses while the cursor is inside a TextWidget will not trigger the event (unless it is a navigation to another object) because TextWidget handles its own key presses.

If the focused view didn't want this event, this method is called.

The default implementation takes care of KeyEvent#KEYCODE_BACK by calling onBackPressed, though the behavior varies based on the application compatibility mode: for

See also:
android.os.Build.VERSION_CODES::ECLAIR

or later applications, it will set up the dispatch to call onKeyUp where the action will be performed; for earlier applications, it will perform the action immediately in on-down, as those versions of the platform behaved.

Other additional default key handling may be performed if configured with setDefaultKeyMode.

Returns:
Return true to prevent this event from being propagated further, or false to indicate that you have not handled this event and it should continue to be propagated.
See also:
onKeyUp, KeyEvent
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onKeyLongPress ( int32_t  keyCode,
KeyEvent *  event 
) [virtual]

Default implementation always returns false (doesn't handle the event).

virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onKeyMultiple ( int32_t  keyCode,
int32_t  repeatCount,
KeyEvent *  event 
) [virtual]

Default implementation always returns false (doesn't handle the event).

virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onKeyShortcut ( int32_t  keyCode,
KeyEvent *  event 
) [virtual]

Called when a key shortcut event is not handled by any of the views in the Page.

Override this method to implement global key shortcuts for the Page.

Parameters:
keyCodeThe value in event.getKeyCode().
eventDescription of the key event.
Returns:
True if the key shortcut was handled.
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onKeyUp ( int32_t  keyCode,
KeyEvent *  event 
) [virtual]

Called when a key was released and not handled by any of the views inside of the page.

So, for example, key presses while the cursor is inside a TextWidget will not trigger the event (unless it is a navigation to another object) because TextWidget handles its own key presses.

The default implementation handles KEYCODE_BACK to stop the page and go back.

Returns:
Return true to prevent this event from being propagated further, or false to indicate that you have not handled this event and it should continue to be propagated.
See also:
onKeyDown, KeyEvent
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onLowMemory ( ) [virtual]
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onNewDemand ( Demand *  demand) [protected, virtual]

This is called for pages that set launchMode to "singleTop" in their package, or if a client used the Demand#FLAG_PAGE_SINGLE_TOP flag when calling startPage.

In either case, when the page is re-launched while at the top of the page stack instead of a new instance of the page being started, onNewdialogue() will be called on the existing instance with the Demand that was used to re-launch it.

An page will always be paused before receiving a new dialogue, so you can count on onResume being called after this method.

Note that getDemand still returns the original Demand. You can use setDemand to update it to this new Demand.

Parameters:
demandThe new dialogue that was started for the page.
See also:
getDemand, setDemand, onResume
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onOptionsItemSelected ( MenuItem *  item) [virtual]

This hook is called whenever an item in your options menu is selected.

The default implementation simply returns false to have the normal processing happen (calling the item's Runnable or sending a message to its Handler as appropriate). You can use this method for any items for which you would like to do processing without those other facilities.

Derived classes should call through to the base class for it to perform the default menu handling.

Parameters:
itemThe menu item that was selected.
Returns:
boolean Return false to allow normal menu processing to proceed, true to consume it here.
See also:
onCreateOptionsMenu
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onPageResult ( int32_t  requestCode,
int32_t  resultCode,
Demand *  data 
) [protected, virtual]

Called when an activity you launched exits, giving you the requestCode you started it with, the resultCode it returned, and any additional data from it.

The resultCode will be RESULT_CANCELED if the activity explicitly returned that, didn't return any result, or crashed during its operation.

You will receive this call immediately before onResume() when your activity is re-starting.

Parameters:
requestCodeThe integer request code originally supplied to startPageForResult, allowing you to identify who this result came from.
resultCodeThe integer result code returned by the child page through its setResult.
dataAn Demand, which can return result data to the caller (various data can be attached to Demand "extras").
See also:
startPageForResult, #createPendingResult, #setResult(int)
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onPause ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called as part of the page lifecycle when a page is going into the background, but has not (yet) been killed.

The counterpart to onResume.

When page B is launched in front of page A, this callback will be invoked on A. B will not be created until A's onPause returns, so be sure to not do anything lengthy here.

This callback is mostly used for saving any persistent state the page is editing, to present a "edit in place" model to the user and making sure nothing is lost if there are not enough resources to start the new page without first killing this one. This is also a good place to do things like stop animations and other things that consume a noticeable mount of CPU in order to make the switch to the next page as fast as possible, or to close resources that are exclusive access such as the camera.

In situations where the system needs more memory it may kill paused processes to reclaim resources. Because of this, you should be sure that all of your state is saved by the time you return from this function. In general onSaveInstanceState is used to save per-instance state in the page and this method is used to store global persistent data (in content providers, files, etc.)

After receiving this call you will usually receive a following call to onStop (after the next page has been resumed and displayed), however in some cases there will be a direct call back to onResume without going through the stopped state.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onResume, onSaveInstanceState, onStop
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onPostInit ( Persistence *  savedInstanceState) [protected, virtual]

Called when activity start-up is complete (after onStart and onRestoreInstanceState have been called).

Applications will generally not implement this method; it is intended for system classes to do final initialization after application code has run.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
savedInstanceStateIf the activity is being re-initialized after previously being shut down then this Bundle contains the data it most recently supplied in onSaveInstanceState. Note: Otherwise it is null.
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onPostResume ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called when activity resume is complete (after onResume has been called).

Applications will generally not implement this method; it is intended for system classes to do final setup after application resume code has run.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onResume
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onPrepareOptionsMenu ( Menu *  menu) [virtual]

Prepare the Screen's standard options menu to be displayed.

This is called right before the menu is shown, every time it is shown. You can use this method to efficiently enable/disable items or otherwise dynamically modify the contents.

The default implementation updates the system menu items based on the activity's state. Deriving classes should always call through to the base class implementation.

Parameters:

Returns:
You must return true for the menu to be displayed; if you return false it will not be shown.
See also:

virtual int32_t gaia::core::Page::onPrepareTheme ( gaia::content::Configuration *  newConfig) [virtual]
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onRestart ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called after onStop when the current page is being re-displayed to the user (the user has navigated back to it).

It will be followed by onStart and then onResume.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onStop, onStart, onResume
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onRestoreInstanceState ( Persistence *  savedInstanceState) [protected, virtual]

This method is called after onStart when the page is being re-initialized from a previously saved state, given here in savedInstanceState.

Most implementations will simply use onInit" to restore their state, but it is sometimes convenient to do it here after all of the initialization has been done or to allow subclasses to decide whether to use your default implementation. The default implementation of this method performs a restore of any view state that had previously been frozen by onSaveInstanceState.

savedInstanceState The data most recently supplied in onSaveInstanceState.

See also:
onInit, onResume, onSaveInstanceState
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onResume ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called after onRestoreInstanceState, onRestart, or onPause, for your page to start interacting with the user.

This is a good place to begin animations, open exclusive-access devices (such as the camera), etc.

Keep in mind that onResume is not the best indicator that your page is visible to the user; a system window such as the keyguard may be in front. Use onWindowFocusChanged to know for certain that your page is visible to the user (for example, to resume a game).

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onRestoreInstanceState, onRestart, onPause
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onSaveInstanceState ( Persistence *  outState) [protected, virtual]

Called to retrieve per-instance state from a page before being killed so that the state can be restored in onInit or onRestoreInstanceState (the Persistence populated by this method will be passed to both).

This method is called before a page may be killed so that when it comes back some time in the future it can restore its state. For example, if page B is launched in front of page A, and at some point page A is killed to reclaim resources, page A will have a chance to save the current state of its user interface via this method so that when the user returns to page A, the state of the user interface can be restored via onInit or onRestoreInstanceState.

Do not confuse this method with page lifecycle callbacks such as onPause, which is always called when a page is being placed in the background or on its way to destruction, or onStop which is called before destruction. One example of when onPause and onStop is called and not this method is when a user navigates back from page B to page A: there is no need to call onSaveInstanceState on B because that particular instance will never be restored, so the system avoids calling it. An example when onPause is called and not onSaveInstanceState is when page B is launched in front of page A: the system may avoid calling onSaveInstanceState on page A if it isn't killed during the lifetime of B since the state of the user interface of A will stay intact.

The default implementation takes care of most of the UI per-instance state for you by calling Widget#onSaveInstanceState() on each view in the hierarchy that has an id, and by saving the id of the currently focused view (all of which is restored by the default implementation of onRestoreInstanceState). If you override this method to save additional information not captured by each individual view, you will likely want to call through to the default implementation, otherwise be prepared to save all of the state of each view yourself.

If called, this method will occur before onStop. There are no guarantees about whether it will occur before or after onPause.

Parameters:
outStatePersistence in which to place your saved state.
See also:
onInit, onRestoreInstanceState, onPause
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onSearchRequested ( ) [virtual]

This hook is called when the user signals the desire to start a search.

You can use this function as a simple way to launch the search UI, in response to a menu item, search button, or other widgets within your activity. Unless overidden, calling this function is the same as calling startSearch, which launches search for the current activity as specified in its manifest, see SearchManager.

You can override this function to force global search, e.g. in response to a dedicated search key, or to block search entirely (by simply returning false).

Returns:
Returns true if search launched, and false if activity blocks it. The default implementation always returns true.
See also:
SearchManager
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onStart ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called after onInit — or after onRestart when the page had been stopped, but is now again being displayed to the user.

It will be followed by onResume.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onInit, onStop, onResume
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onStop ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called when you are no longer visible to the user.

You will next receive either onRestart, onTear, or nothing, depending on later user page.

Note that this method may never be called, in low memory situations where the system does not have enough memory to keep your page's process running after its onPause method is called.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onRestart, onResume, onSaveInstanceState, onTear
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onTear ( ) [protected, virtual]

Perform any final cleanup before a page is destroyed.

This can happen either because the page is finishing (someone called finish on it, or because the system is temporarily destroying this instance of the page to save space. You can distinguish between these two scenarios with the isFinishing method.

Note: do not count on this method being called as a place for saving data! For example, if a page is editing data in a content provider, those edits should be committed in either onPause or onSaveInstanceState, not here. This method is usually implemented to free resources like threads that are associated with a page, so that a destroyed page does not leave such things around while the rest of its application is still running. There are situations where the system will simply kill the page's hosting process without calling this method (or any others) in it, so it should not be used to do things that are intended to remain around after the process goes away.

Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

See also:
onPause, onStop, finish, isFinishing
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onTitleChanged ( gaia::base::String  title,
int32_t  color 
) [protected, virtual]
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onTouchEvent ( MotionEvent *  event) [virtual]

Called when a touch screen event was not handled by any of the views under it.

This is most useful to process touch events that happen outside of your window bounds, where there is no view to receive it.

Parameters:
eventThe touch screen event being processed.
Returns:
Return true if you have consumed the event, false if you haven't. The default implementation always returns false.
virtual bool gaia::core::Page::onTrackballEvent ( MotionEvent *  event) [virtual]

Called when the trackball was moved and not handled by any of the views inside of the page.

So, for example, if the trackball moves while focus is on a button, you will receive a call here because buttons do not normally do anything with trackball events. The call here happens before trackball movements are converted to DPAD key events, which then get sent back to the view hierarchy, and will be processed at the point for things like focus navigation.

Parameters:
eventThe trackball event being processed.
Returns:
Return true if you have consumed the event, false if you haven't. The default implementation always returns false.
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onTrimMemory ( int32_t  level) [virtual]

This is called when the overall system is running low on memory, and would like actively running process to try to tighten their belt.

Parameters:
levelTrim memory level.
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onUserInteraction ( ) [virtual]

Called whenever a key, touch, or trackball event is dispatched to the page.

Implement this method if you wish to know that the user has interacted with the device in some way while your page is running. This callback and onUserLeaveHint are intended to help pages manage status bar notifications intelligently; specifically, for helping pages determine the proper time to cancel a notfication.

All calls to your page's onUserLeaveHint callback will be accompanied by calls to onUserInteraction. This ensures that your page will be told of relevant user page such as pulling down the notification pane and touching an item there.

Note that this callback will be invoked for the touch down action that begins a touch gesture, but may not be invoked for the touch-moved and touch-up actions that follow.

See also:
onUserLeaveHint
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onUserLeaveHint ( ) [protected, virtual]

Called as part of the page lifecycle when a page is about to go into the background as the result of user choice.

For example, when the user presses the Home key, onUserLeaveHint will be called, but when an incoming phone call causes the in-call Page to be automatically brought to the foreground, onUserLeaveHint will not be called on the page being interrupted. In cases when it is invoked, this method is called right before the page's onPause callback.

This callback and onUserInteraction are intended to help pages manage status bar notifications intelligently; specifically, for helping pages determine the proper time to cancel a notfication.

See also:
onUserInteraction
virtual void gaia::core::Page::onWindowFocusChanged ( bool  hasFocus) [virtual]

Called when the current Window of the page gains or loses focus.

This is the best indicator of whether this page is visible to the user. The default implementation clears the key tracking state, so should always be called.

Note that this provides information about global focus state, which is managed independently of page lifecycles. As such, while focus changes will generally have some relation to lifecycle changes (an page that is stopped will not generally get window focus), you should not rely on any particular order between the callbacks here and those in the other lifecycle methods such as onResume.

As a general rule, however, a resumed page will have window focus... unless it has displayed other dialogs or popups that take input focus, in which case the page itself will not have focus when the other windows have it. Likewise, the system may display system-level windows (such as the status bar notification panel or a system alert) which will temporarily take window input focus without pausing the foreground page.

Parameters:
hasFocusWhether the window of this page has focus.
See also:
hasWindowFocus(), onResume
void gaia::core::Page::overridePendingTransition ( int32_t  enterAnim,
int32_t  exitAnim 
)

Call immediately after one of the flavors of startPage or finish to specify an explicit transition animation to perform next.

Parameters:
enterAnimA resource ID of the animation resource to use for the incoming activity. Use 0 for no animation.
exitAnimA resource ID of the animation resource to use for the outgoing activity. Use 0 for no animation.
void gaia::core::Page::recreate ( )

Cause this Page to be recreated with a new instance.

This results in essentially the same flow as when the Page is created due to a configuration change -- the current instance will go through its lifecycle to #onDestroy and a new instance then created after it.

void* gaia::core::Page::revokeDelegate ( Demand *  demand)

Use the demand to revoke the delegate.

Parameters:
demandDemand to revoke the Delegate.
void gaia::core::Page::setActivityProxy ( ActivityProxy *  pageProxy) [protected]
void gaia::core::Page::setDefaultKeyMode ( int32_t  mode)

Select the default key handling for this page.

This controls what will happen to key events that are not otherwise handled. The default mode (DEFAULT_KEYS_DISABLE) will simply drop them on the floor. Other modes allow you to launch the dialer (DEFAULT_KEYS_DIALER), execute a shortcut in your options menu without requiring the menu key be held down (DEFAULT_KEYS_SHORTCUT), or launch a search (DEFAULT_KEYS_SEARCH_LOCAL and DEFAULT_KEYS_SEARCH_GLOBAL).

Note that the mode selected here does not impact the default handling of system keys, such as the "back" and "menu" keys, and your page and its views always get a first chance to receive and handle all application keys.

Parameters:
modeThe desired default key mode constant.
See also:

void gaia::core::Page::setSecondaryProgress ( int32_t  secondaryProgress)

Sets the secondary progress for the progress bar in the title.

This progress is drawn between the primary progress (set via setProgress) and the background. It can be ideal for media scenarios such as showing the buffering progress while the default progress shows the play progress.

Parameters:
secondaryProgressThe secondary progress for the progress bar. Valid ranges are from 0 to 10000 (both inclusive).

void gaia::core::Page::setVisible ( bool  visible)

Control whether this activity's main window is visible.

This is intended only for the special case of an activity that is not going to show a UI itself, but can't just finish prior to onResume because it needs to wait for a service binding or such. Setting this to false allows you to prevent your UI from being shown during that time.

The default value for this is taken from the

See also:
android.R.attr::windowNoDisplay

attribute of the activity's theme.

void gaia::core::Page::setVolumeControlStream ( int32_t  streamType)

Suggests an audio stream whose volume should be changed by the hardware volume controls.

The suggested audio stream will be tied to the window of this Page. If the Page is switched, the stream set here is no longer the suggested stream. The client does not need to save and restore the old suggested stream value in onPause and onResume.

Parameters:
streamTypeThe type of the audio stream whose volume should be changed by the hardware volume controls. It is not guaranteed that the hardware volume controls will always change this stream's volume (for example, if a call is in progress, its stream's volume may be changed instead). To reset back to the default, use AudioManager::USE_DEFAULT_STREAM_TYPE.
void gaia::core::Page::startManagingCursor ( const gaia::storage::Cursor &  c)

This method allows the activity to take care of managing the given Cursor's lifecycle for you based on the activity's lifecycle.

That is, when the activity is stopped it will automatically call Cursor#deactivate on the given Cursor, and when it is later restarted it will call Cursor#requery for you. When the activity is destroyed, all managed Cursors will be closed automatically.

Parameters:
cThe Cursor to be managed.
See also:
stopManagingCursor
bool gaia::core::Page::startNextMatchingPage ( Demand *  demand)

Special version of starting an activity, for use when you are replacing other activity components.

You can use this to hand the Demand off to the next Page that can handle it. You typically call this in #onCreate with the Demand returned by getDemand.

Parameters:
intentThe intent to dispatch to the next activity. For correct behavior, this must be the same as the Demand that started your own activity; the only changes you can make are to the extras inside of it.
Returns:
Returns a boolean indicating whether there was another Page to start: true if there was a next activity to start, false if there wasn't. In general, if true is returned you will then want to call finish on yourself.
virtual void gaia::core::Page::startPage ( Demand *  demand) [virtual]

Launch a new activity.

You will not receive any information about when the activity exits. This implementation overrides the base version, providing information about the activity performing the launch. Because of this additional information, the Demand#FLAG_PAGE_NEW_TASK launch flag is not required; if not specified, the new activity will be added to the task of the caller.

Parameters:
intentThe intent to start.
See also:
startPageForResult
void gaia::core::Page::startPageForResult ( Demand *  demand,
int32_t  requestCode 
)

Launch an activity for which you would like a result when it finished.

When this activity exits, your onPageResult method will be called with the given requestCode. Using a negative requestCode is the same as calling startPage (the activity is not launched as a sub-activity).

Note that this method should only be used with Demand protocols that are defined to return a result. In other protocols (such as Demand#ACTION_MAIN or Demand#ACTION_VIEW), you may not get the result when you expect. For example, if the activity you are launching uses the singleTask launch mode, it will not run in your task and thus you will immediately receive a cancel result.

As a special case, if you call startPageForResult with a requestCode >= 0 during the initial onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState)/ onResume of your activity, then your window will not be displayed until a result is returned back from the started activity. This is to avoid visible flickering when redirecting to another activity.

Parameters:
intentThe intent to start.
requestCodeIf >= 0, this code will be returned in onPageResult when the activity exits.
See also:
startPage
void gaia::core::Page::startPageFromChild ( Page *  child,
Demand *  demand,
int32_t  requestCode 
)

This is called when a child activity of this one calls its startPage or startPageForResult method.

Parameters:
childThe activity making the call.
demandThe demand to start.
requestCodeReply request code. < 0 if reply is not requested.
See also:
startPage, startPageForResult
bool gaia::core::Page::startPageIfNeeded ( Demand *  demand,
int32_t  requestCode 
)

A special variation to launch an activity only if a new activity instance is needed to handle the given Demand.

In other words, this is just like startPageForResult except: if you are using the Demand#FLAG_PAGE_SINGLE_TOP flag, or singleTask or singleTop

See also:
android.R.styleable::AndroidManifestPage_launchMode launchMode

, and the activity that handles intent is the same as your currently running activity, then a new instance is not needed. In this case, instead of the normal behavior of calling onNewDemand this function will return and you can handle the Demand yourself.

This function can only be called from a top-level activity; if it is called from a child activity, a runtime exception will be thrown.

Parameters:
intentThe intent to start.
requestCodeIf >= 0, this code will be returned in onPageResult when the activity exits, as described in startPageForResult.
Returns:
If a new activity was launched then true is returned; otherwise false is returned and you must handle the Demand your self.
See also:
startPage, startPageForResult
virtual void gaia::core::Page::startPages ( const gaia::base::Vector< Demand * > &  demands) [virtual]

Launch a new activity.

You will not receive any information about when the activity exits. This implementation overrides the base version, providing information about the activity performing the launch. Because of this additional information, the Demand#FLAG_PAGE_NEW_TASK launch flag is not required; if not specified, the new activity will be added to the task of the caller.

Parameters:
demandsThe demands to start.
See also:
startPageForResult
void gaia::core::Page::startSearch ( gaia::base::String  initialQuery,
bool  selectInitialQuery,
Persistence *  appSearchData,
bool  globalSearch 
)

This hook is called to launch the search UI.

It is typically called from onSearchRequested(), either directly from onSearchRequested or from an overridden version in any given Page. If your goal is simply to activate search, it is preferred to call onSearchRequested, which may have been overriden elsewhere in your Page. If your goal is to inject specific data such as context data, it is preferred to override onSearchRequested, so that any callers to it will benefit from the override.

Parameters:
initialQueryAny non-null non-empty string will be inserted as pre-entered text in the search query box.
selectInitialQueryIf true, the intial query will be preselected, which means that any further typing will replace it. This is useful for cases where an entire pre-formed query is being inserted. If false, the selection point will be placed at the end of the inserted query. This is useful when the inserted query is text that the user entered, and the user would expect to be able to keep typing. This parameter is only meaningful if initialQuery is a non-empty string.
appSearchDataAn application can insert application-specific context here, in order to improve quality or specificity of its own searches. This data will be returned with SEARCH intent(s). Null if no extra data is required.
globalSearchIf false, this will only launch the search that has been specifically defined by the application (which is usually defined as a local search). If no default search is defined in the current application or activity, global search will be launched. If true, this will always launch a platform-global (e.g. web-based) search instead.
See also:
SearchManager, onSearchRequested
void gaia::core::Page::stopManagingCursor ( const gaia::storage::Cursor &  c)

Given a Cursor that was previously given to startManagingCursor, stop the activity's management of that cursor.

Parameters:
cThe Cursor that was being managed.
See also:
startManagingCursor
void gaia::core::Page::takeKeyEvents ( bool  get)

Use this if your activity has no views with focus, but the activity still wants a chance to process key events.

void gaia::core::Page::triggerSearch ( gaia::base::String  query,
Persistence *  appSearchData 
)

Similar to startSearch, but actually fires off the search query after invoking the search dialog.

Made available for testing purposes.

Parameters:
queryThe query to trigger. If empty, the request will be ignored.
appSearchDataAn application can insert application-specific context here, in order to improve quality or specificity of its own searches. This data will be returned with SEARCH intent(s). Null if no extra data is required.

const int32_t gaia::core::Page::DEFAULT_KEYS_SHORTCUT = 2 [static]

Use with setDefaultKeyMode to execute a menu shortcut in default key handling.

That is, the user does not need to hold down the menu key to execute menu shortcuts.
